review.body: Very deceiving title. Basically a choppy out of order history book filled with opinionated viewpoints. Very difficult to follow as it’s all over the place. One of the worst reads I’ve endured tbh. Really not my sort of book.

book.title: Stolen Pen Pals (Pen Pals, #9)
book.description: Shannon, Lisa, Palmer and Amy have just discovered that some girls from a rival school have stolen their idea by putting an ad in the paper looking for boy pen pals! They have to figure out a way to keep them from stealing all the eligible boys.

review.body: Most of the people in this book acted completely out of character and almost every character was portrayed as being completely dense. Not a favourite at all.
Love the way the series ended. This book and the first are my favourites.

book.title: The Magic Pudding: Third Slice
book.description: Bunyip Bluegum would never have met Bill Barnacle, the sailor, his friend Sam Sawnoff, the penguin bold, and Albert, the magic pudding, if it had not been for his Uncle Wattleberry's whiskers. For it was on account of these whiskers that Bunyip decided to leave home and become a travelling gentleman of leisure.

review.body: Nowhere near as good as the first two books in the series. The kids got bored very quickly and I found I basically just read it to myself.

book.title: Sealed with a Kiss (Pen Pals, #8)
book.description: Ardsley and Alma have joined forces for a production of a romantic rock musical and Lisa's pen pal Rob has the male lead. Lisa wants to play opposite him but Amy gets the part. Now Lisa is wondering if her best friend and her pen pal are more than just acting when their characters have to kiss.

review.body: Loved this book. Probably one of the best in the series. Loved the way the friction between the characters was dealt with.

book.title: Handle With Care (Pen Pals, #7)
book.description: Tired of being in her best friend Lisa's shadow, Shanon decides to correct the problem and run against Lisa in the student council election. Not only does the election come between the two girls, but also between Lisa and her pen pal Rob.

review.body: Probably my favourite pen pals book so far. Less of Palmer and more of the other girls.

book.title: Ten In The Bed
book.description: There were ten in the bed and the little one said Roll over, roll over! But who were the ten? And what happened to them all after they rolled out of bed? All is revealed in this bedtime tale featuring a small child and an assortment of soft toys.

review.body: Quite a cute little twist to the original. The pics made it look like the ‘little one’ was a little turd that treated his toys terribly though.

book.title: TinkerBell and the Lost Treasure: The Junior Novelization
book.title_without_series: TinkerBell and the Lost Treasure: The Junior Novelization
book.description:
Return to Pixie Hollow for a brand-new movie adventure with Tinker Bell!

Tinker Bell is thrilled when she is selected to make the prestigious Autumn Scepter to commemorate the rare Blue Moon. Her friend Terence tries to help, but he ends up getting in the way—and on Tink’s nerves. Then, to make matters worse, Tink accidentally breaks the scepter’s moonstone! So she must travel north of Never Land to find the one thing that can fix the moonstone—the magical Mirror of Incanta. It’s a rough journey, but Tink is helped along by a firefly named Blaze. Can Tink mend the scepter—and her friendship with Terence—before the Blue Moon rises? Find out in the Junior Novelization retelling of Tinker Bell and the Lost Treasure, featuring eight pages of full-color scenes from the direct-to-DVD movie!

review.body: A gorgeous tale about the importance of friendship. Lovely pictures to keep the kids interested.
Some cool ideas, though more of an activity book than a story about being on a farm.

book.title: Amy's Song (Pen Pals, #6)
book.description: On a class trip to London, Amy has the chance to show her musical talents in a real club. She is going to sing a song she and her pen pal, John, wrote together. Although Amy likes her own lyrics better, she agrees to use John's for the sake of friendship. But flustered midstream, she uses her own lyrics. Will John forgive her?

review.body: The characters seemed to act so unlike their personalities in the previous books, particularly Amy. At least Palmer wasn’t so annoying in this one.

book.title: Little Miss Whoops
book.description: Miss Whoops keeps having accidents. Miss Whoops takes a trip to see her brother Mr. Bump.

review.body: Makes the kids clumsiness seem minor in comparison. Not a bad little book, but certainly not the best of the Little Miss series.

book.title: Little Miss Bad (Little Miss Books, #32)
book.description: Little Miss Bad is not good. Far from it. In fact, about as far as you can get, which is a long way! Can Little Miss Sunshine trick Little Miss Bad into confessing all her wrongdoings?

review.body: What a cheeky way to catch someone out. Very clever - and not an ounce of sympathy for Little Miss Bad.

book.title: Little Miss Scary
book.description: Little Miss Scary loves to scare the socks off of the other Mr. Men and Little Misses. But can she handle it when the tables are turned?

review.body: A quick little bedtime tale with a lot of little lessons. Despite being about someone called ‘Little Miss Scary’ the book itself isn’t scary to the kids at all. At least not the ones I’m reading to.

book.title: Little Miss Somersault
book.description:
They're back! Rediscover the zaniest characters you've ever met in this best-selling series which has sold millions worldwide. Bright and charming, with easily recognizable characters and a small take-along format, Mr. Men and Little Miss books are easy enough for young readers, witty enough for humor-prone adults, and highly collectible for one and all. Also check your local listings to view the Mr. Men & Little Miss TV show.

Back to the Mr. Men & Little Miss microsite.

review.body: I like that this particular Little Miss tale tackles a common fear, allowing children to realise fears are a normal thing to be faced with and not something to be ashamed of.

book.title: Little Miss Contrary
book.description: Little Miss Contrary says the exact opposite of what she means. This can get very confusing unless you know Little Miss Contrary well! She lives in Muddleland, where everything, as you can probably guess is a bit of a muddle. If you ever run into Little Miss Contrary, let's hope she doesn't give you a compliment!

review.body: I don’t think Little Miss Contrary was quite the right name for this character.

book.title: Little Miss Fun
book.description: Come join the fun with Little Miss Fun. She's always the life of the party-even after her guests are asleep!

review.body: A perfect ending for a bedtime story for the kids. Short, sweet and with cute little pictures.

book.title: Little Miss Curious
book.description: They're back! Rediscover the zaniest characters you've ever met in this bestselling series which has sold millions worldwide. Just in time for Fall 1997's hot new animated TV show, Mr. Men and Little Miss "TM" are being relaunched in the U.S. Bright and charming, with easily recognizable characters and a small take-along format, Mr. Men and Little Miss "TM" books are easy enough for young readers, witty enough for humor-prone adults, and highly collectible for one and all. Great crosssover potential -- again!Why ask why, Little Miss Curious?

review.body: Don’t read this book to the kids right before bed unless you want to be asked a series of impossible-to-answer questions.

book.title: Little Miss Stubborn
book.description: Little Miss Stubborn hates being told what she can andcan't do, so she does whatever she wants!

review.body: This book had so much potential for important lessons and strong morals to the story, all of which were ignored, making the ending quite disappointing.

book.title: Little Miss Brainy
book.description: Little Miss Brainy is the smartest Little Miss around. But her brains can gether into trouble sometimes. Full-color illustrations.

review.body: Being intelligent isn’t all it’s cracked up to be. Poor little Miss Brainy.

book.title: Little Miss Fickle
book.description: Little Miss Fickle finds it impossible to make up her mind about anything.

review.body: I think we have all been in Little Miss Fickle’s position at some point in our lives - especially us avid readers!

book.title: Little Miss Greedy
book.description: Little Miss Greedy loves to eat: She has 66 sausages and 23 pieces of toast for breakfast! And readers will love to see what she takes along with her when Mr. Greedy invites her to tea . . .

review.body: This book had a lot more potential.

book.title: Little Miss Tidy
book.description: An exciting addition to the hugely successful 'Little Miss' range, this book is perfect for use in school, during class reading and for parents reading along with their children at home.

review.body: While this is a cute little tale, I’m not sure the kids got the right message from the book. Now they’re too ‘scared’ to tidy up in case they lose stuff.

book.title: Little Miss Wise
book.description:
They're back! Rediscover the zaniest characters you've ever met in this best-selling series which has sold millions worldwide. Bright and charming, with easily recognizable characters and a small take-along format, Mr. Men and Little Miss books are easy enough for young readers, witty enough for humor-prone adults, and highly collectible for one and all. Also check your local listings to view the Mr. Men & Little Miss TV show.

Back to the Mr Men & Little Miss microsite.

review.body: This book had a lot of potential to share some very important lessons, but fell short every time. Not the most productive of the Little Miss books.

book.title: Little Miss Quick
book.description: Little Miss Quick does everything as quickly as possible! Unfortunately, "quickly" also usually means means "carelessly." And when she tries to help her friends but messes up everything instead, she finds herself in a lot of trouble!

review.body: A good little book that shows that quickest isn’t always best. You usually get a better result when you don’t rush things.

book.title: Little Miss Busy
book.description:
Little Miss Busy is always on the go, from the moment she wakes up until she falls asleep at night. Nothing can slow her down--until she gets sick! Suddenly, Little Miss Busy needs to learn how to rest, which turns out to be the hardest thing of all.

Rediscover the zaniest characters you've ever met in this best-selling series which has sold millions of copies worldwide. Bright and charming, with easily recognizable characters and a small take-along format, the Mr. Men Little Miss stories are easy enough for young readers, witty enough for humor-prone adults, and highly collectible for one and all.

review.body: As someone who always likes to keep busy, I quite liked this book. Especially since I have just had surgery and am trying to learn to do nothing whilst I heal. Hence why I’m going back through and reading all these little books again.

book.title: Little Miss Star
book.description: Little Miss Star is not the famous star she'd like to be just yet?but that's all about to change!

review.body: What a lovely little tale that almost any child can relate to at some stage of their life. I loved how it ended.

book.title: Little Miss Scatterbrain
book.description:
Mr. Men and Little Miss?Get ready for the second invasion of Little Miss and Little Mr. Men! That's right - those zany, pint-sized characters are back. Easy enough for young readers and witty enough for adults!Little Miss Scatterbrain is so forgetful! No wonder she has trouble with her daily chores.

Back to the Mr. Men & Little Miss microsite.

review.body: A funny little tale about Little Miss Scatterbrain’s forgetfulness. Sounds more like pregnancy brain to me.

book.title: Little Miss Lucky
book.description: Little Miss Lucky is anything but?.However did she get that name?

review.body: This book has a different feel to it in comparison to the other books in the series.

book.title: Little Miss Late
book.description: Little Miss Late is never on time-until she gets a job working for Mr. Lazy!

review.body: While this is a good little book, it reads almost the same as an earlier book in the series, Little Miss Chatterbox. Same jobs, in the same order with the same characters. Basically the same book with a different Little Miss character.
A cute little book that the kids enjoyed, but no moral to the story.

book.title: Little Miss Chatterbox
book.description: When Little Miss Chatterbox starts a sentence, it goes on and on and on . . .

review.body: What an adorable little book. Just goes to show that no matter what your personality, there’s a place in the world just for you.

book.title: Little Miss Twins
book.description: Travel to Twoland where two friends can be double the fun fun!!

review.body: I think this is probably the most annoying Little Miss book I e read so far. Was irritating to read to the kids and I’m glad they weren’t keen for me to read it again.

book.title: Little Miss Splendid
book.description: Miss Splendid thinks herself a thoroughly superior creature and too good for any of the earth's common things.

review.body: Love how Miss Splendid gets her just desserts! Great little book for the kids.

book.title: Little Miss Shy
book.description:
When Little Miss Shy gets an invitation to Mr. Funny's party, she goes into hiding!

Back to the Mr. Men & Little Miss microsite.

review.body: A great little book for children who are shy and don’t like to socialise much.

book.title: Little Miss Magic
book.description: Mr. Tickle's tickling is out of control! Can Little Miss Magic conjure up a silution?

review.body: A cute little book with a very cheeky ending.

book.title: Little Miss Helpful
book.description: Little Miss Helpful means well, but with help like hers--you'd better be careful!

review.body: This is so cute... and so accurate! I think we all know someone a little like Little Miss Helpful.

book.title: Little Miss Giggles
book.description: They're back! Rediscover the zaniest characters you've ever met in this best-selling series which has sold millions worldwide. Just in time for Fall 1997's hot new animated TV show, "Mr. Men" and "Little Miss" are being relaunched in the U. S. Bright and charming, with easily recognizable characters and a small take-along format, "Mr. Men" and "Little Miss" books are easy enough for young readers, witty enough for humor-prone adults, and highly collectible for one and all.

review.body: A bit of a sad little tale with a happy ending. Still a cute little book.

book.title: Little Miss Trouble
book.description:
Uh-oh! It's time for Little Miss Trouble to get a taste of her own medicine.

Back to the Mr. Men & Little Miss microsite.

review.body: Another one with a great ending. Great first book when teaching a child about karma.

book.title: Little Miss Sunshine
book.description: They're back! Rediscover the zaniest characters you've ever met in this best-selling series which has sold millions worldwide. Just in time for Fall 1997's hot new animated TV show, "Mr. Men" and "Little Miss" are being relaunched in the U. S. Bright and charming, with easily recognizable characters and a small take-along format, "Mr. Men" and "Little Miss" books are easy enough for young readers, witty enough for humor-prone adults, and highly collectible for one and all.

review.body: Another cute little miss book that shows that blending in with what is expected is not always the best way to live.

book.title: Little Miss Neat
book.description: Get ready for the second invasion of Little Miss and Little Mr. Men! That's right - those zany, pint-sized characters are back. Easy enough for young readers and witty enough for adults!Little Miss Neat keeps her home as tidy as can be -- until Mr. Muddle comes to visit!

review.body: A cute little book, but not as good as the others in the series in my opinion.

book.title: Little Miss Naughty
book.description:
Mr. Men and Little Miss?Get ready for the second invasion of Little Miss and Little Mr. Men! That's right - those zany, pint-sized characters are back. Easy enough for young readers and witty enough for adults!Little Miss Naughty terrorizes the neighborhood until she meets her match -- Mr. Impossible!

Back to the Mr. Men & Little Miss microsite.

review.body: This is my favourite little miss book. I used to be quite naughty as a child (no surprises there) and I spose I’ve always been able to relate to this one the most.

book.title: Little Miss Bossy
book.description:
Little Miss Bossy tells everyone what to do-until Wilfred the Wizard casts a spell on her.

Back to the Mr. Men & Little Miss microsite.

review.body: What an adorable little book. Absolutely loved the ending.

book.title: A Year on the Farm (DK Readers L1)
book.description:
Follow the busy lives of Mr. and Mrs. Farmer through A Year on the Farm, looking after the animals and growing crops. Look out for the busy Red Tractor who's helping out! Level 1 books are stories for children just beginning to learn to read. They use short, simple sentences, simple vocabulary, word repetition, and large type. Strong visual clues help children with new words. Lively stories feature characters and topics that are familiar to young children.

Whether your child is learning how to read or wants to practice and improve his or her reading skills, DK Readers have the right story for developmentally appropriate reading at home. This innovative range of graded readers combines a highly visual approach with stories that children will want to read. Easy-to-read stories for beginning readers with word repetition progress to stories with rich vocabulary and more challenging sentence structure. There's a DK Reader for every child!

review.body: A cute little book with awesome pictures and lots of information for the kids. Now they want to start growing potatoes and get a pet cow. Awesome!!

book.title: Over in the Meadow (Little Golden Book)

review.body: Gorgeous pictures and a catchy rhyme. Easy to read to the kids and get them involved.
Not as good as the first book, but still interesting and has catchy song-song lyrics. Not as many pictures and therefore not as easy to keep the younger kids focussed on the story.

book.title: A Slice of Magic Pudding
book.description: Young Australia Series, Written and Illustrated by Norman Lindsay, Very clean unmarked book and pages,

review.body: Such a brilliant little book with adorable pictures. I loved this book as a child and reading it again now brings back so many memories. Very catchy wording and fun to read aloud to the kids in a sing-song voice.

book.title: The Stand
book.description: This is the way the world ends: with a nanosecond of computer error in a Defense Department laboratory and a million casual contacts that form the links in a chain letter of death. And here is the bleak new world of the day after: a world stripped of its institutions and emptied of 99 percent of its people. A world in which a handful of panicky survivors choose sides -- or are chosen.

review.body: A good story, but it does drag on a bit. I found myself quite bored in some parts.

book.title: The Suspect (Joe O'Loughlin #1)
book.description:
Joseph O'Loughlin appears to have the perfect life - a beautiful wife, a loving daughter and a successful career as a clinical psychologist. But nothing can be taken for granted. Even the most flawless existence is only a loose thread away from unravelling. All it takes is a murdered girl, a troubled young patient and the biggest lie of his life.

Caught in a complex web of deceit and haunted by images of the slain girl, he embarks upon a search that will take him from London to Liverpool and into the darkest recesses of the human mind...

**Includes BONUS first chapter of the explosive new Joe O'Loughlin thriller, THE OTHER WIFE**

review.body:
Brilliant

Love the writing style, the characters and the way in which the story unfolds, without giving away the punch line. Great book. Highly recommend.
Brilliantly written, funny and teaches an important lesson.

The kids got a bit upset over this one. As an adult I am able to see the moral of the story, but for the kids it seemed to be a lose-lose situation, with some animals being left hungry or other animals being eaten. After a lengthy discussion I was able to set things straight, but definitely not a...
A well written story with a very important lesson. Great tale for the kids.
Yet another cute little Enid Blyton book, the stories don’t have a solid moral to them like most of Blyton’s tales though.
A very cute and magical story. Not sure if it installs very good ideas into the minds of children though.

book.title: My Nut I Think! & Pins And Needles
book.title_without_series: My Nut I Think! & Pins And Needles

review.body: What an adorable little book to read the kids at bedtime. Some great messages in the tales too
While this is a cute little tale, it really doesn’t have any lesson I want the kids learning.
A very cute little book that gets young minds thinking and imagining. Adorable little pictures and like all Enid Blyton books, well written.
